Description: Gold finger-ring: the ring is formed from a turquoise green glazed composition scarab as bezel and a hollow gold foil shank folded around wire. A further length of gold wire is wound around one end of the shank, passes through the scarab's pierced length and is wound around the opposite end of the shank to provide the swivelling mechanism. The scarab which is set in a gold mount and has finely marked details on its back is inscribed with the prenomen or throne name of Queen Hatshepsut flanked by hieroglyphs.
Curator's comments: Although such a scarab ring was intended to function as a seal, the form was already being superceded by the solid metal signet. However, it could also be worn as a purely amuletic finger ring with the inscription face downward against the skin since the scarab shape was a potent amulet in its own right. Bibliography: 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999), 282-283 No 88.
